children.subject: +1. I’m currently a sophomore and am currently pursuing a history minor. My case may be a little different than yours, because although I like CS, I’m not as deeply passionate about it as many are here. My history classes are very much a way to keep myself sane and in touch with a community outside of CS/STEM, and thus far I have not regretted my decision.

Personally, I am not as concerned about my "depth" of CS education as an undergrad here, because the courses here do go very deep into topics even as undergrad courses, and most students pick a "focus" like ML, SE, graphics, EE, systems, signals, etc. Also, there is always grad school, which is a good way to get a "depth" of knowledge and have it actually count towards your career (I don't think your pay will go up because you took more CS classes as an undergrad, but in some cases getting your masters places you at a higher position when you enter a company, an dit may be easier to receive a promotion, etc.--at least that's what my brother, who works at Google as a TPM says). 

If you end up liking another subject, I would recommend exploring it. Berkeley outputs a lot of CS students to tech industry and research fields, but I would argue most other academic fields you can explore at Berkeley may also benefit/are benefitting from computer science innovations. It can't hurt to have a depth of knowledge in another field, or a breadth of knowledge in many. Learning a language or two will open career/life opportunities in other countries, going into a humanities or social science topic will at the very least make you a much better writer and reader/researcher, or getting into another STEM field will certainly allow you to go into a career that will probably involve both your CS degree and your STEM knowledge (so many fields like medicine, chemical industry, etc. rely on hardware and software).

Personally, I am double majoring in CS and a humanities degree, and I am finding very interesting ways to combine those topics and having very interesting conversations with faculty here about the intersection between them. I am also able to focus each degree to complement the other, e.g. focusing on graphics in CS and focusing on theoretical/mathematical aspects of my humanities major. I am having a fun time and I recommend you explore as well! I just wouldn't drop your CS degree entirely since you are at a great place for it and its a cushion for your career.

I'm a double major in CS and DS.  My main objective is CS, but I decided to go with the strategy of using breadths to cover some of the requirements for DS (I'm using Cognition as my domain emphasis), plus pick up additional CS classes to fulfill the DS requirements.  By doing this, I've gotten more in depth with CS along with getting the extra degree in data science (not sure if it's worth that much extra combined with CS) and at the same time picking up some domain knowledge in Cognitive Science.  And for me it comes out to one extra semester's worth of classes (well, 5 extra classes actually).

history.content:
Hi everyone. Considering how course selection is coming up soon, I was hoping to get some insight from students who might have once been in my place about the track I should follow for the next 2.5 years at Berkeley (I'm currently a sophomore).

So the main problem for me right now is that I am kind of confused about whether I want to focus completely on CS, making use of the excellent opportunity I have, to get as much technical knowledge that I can. Or should I sacrifice some of that CS depth to explore other fields in Berkeley which also have world-class departments, an opportunity I would probably not be able to get later.

In particular, if I decide to go for greater breadth, I was planning the following: take two tech courses (will almost always be CS Upper Divs but once or twice might be a Math class like 104) and two 'breadths'. For example, I wanted to get a survey of most of the other fields, so I planned on taking Phil 25 A and B, English 45 B and C, History 4 A and B, alongside the International Breadth and AC course. All these courses serve as a broad overview/introduction to their respective fields. This way, my workload is very well balanced and I can enjoy learning about different subjects while also comfortably understanding my CS classes (since I will have a lot of time to work on them). 

The other option is the following: I take 3 techs every semester and choose the easiest, most efficient breadths I need to satisfy the L&S requirements. That way, I graduate in 3 years and enroll in the department's 5th-year Masters plan to get an MS in CS as well. By doing so, I can explore CS much, much more in-depth and since I'm very interested in research (and maybe persuing a PhD) expose myself to intensive CS research (currently doing research as well but much more basic). The only issue is that since I will be taking 3 courses it will be pretty hard but considering my semesters so far I believe I can manage it. I will just not be as comfortable and will need much more discipline/focus than the first option.

My reasoning for the second situation is also because I realize that I can explore other subjects that interest me later by taking online courses and self-studying them through departments that are equally as good as Berkeley's (such as Harvard or MITs online courses). However, it would be very hard for me to self-study the technical courses online since they require a much greater level of interaction and guidance as compared to the breadths. 

 What do you guys think is the best option to go with? For some students who have been in such a situation previously, what path did you end up taking and why? Would you recommend it to your juniors?
history.subject: Dilemma between focusing on CS or exploring other subjects
